title-group.article-title: Review: Gender differences in the quality of life and coping patterns after discharge in patients recovering from burns in China

body.p: This study of burn survivors in China makes an important contribution in further testing whether gender differences in coping patterns observed in North American studies of burn survivors are also observed in another culture. As such, it supports coping and cognitive behavior theories that posit that one’s outlook or appraisal is inextricably linked to coping responses and health outcomes.

The study contributes to the international literature that also demonstrates gender differences in response to illnesses and treatment. This differential response has implications for health and social policies governing eligibility for, and length of, compensation following injury.

Given the role of women in child rearing and housekeeping, the findings also have implications for the nature of social and health supports required by women in these circumstances after discharge. The findings demonstrate the need for nurses to be prepared in recognizing depressive symptomatology, even in cultures reluctant to endorse mental health problems.
In addition, nurses should be prepared to intervene with persons using avoidant coping styles as it is precisely these persons who would refuse a referral to a mental health professional.

bio.p: Gina Browne (PhD, RegN, HonLLD) is founder and director of the Health and Social Service Utilization Research Unit established in 1991 and funded by the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care. She is a professor of Nursing; Clinical Epidemiology & Biostatistics; and Ontario Training Centre in Health Services and Policy Research (OTC) at McMaster University, Faculty of Health Sciences. In 2009, she became the program lead of a Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care-funded Applied Health Research Network Initiative program entitled Innovative and Integrated Systems of Prevention and Care. As a family therapist in primary care, Gina has first-hand knowledge of the mix of challenges faced by many of the most vulnerable citizens and their families. In 2009, Gina received an Honorary Doctor of Laws from Ryerson University in Toronto for her contributions that address social inequities. In September 2010, Gina was awarded the Champion of Human Services Award from the Ontario Municipal Social Services Association (OMSSA) in recognition of her significant impact on human services at a municipal, provincial or federal level.
